author: Si Liberman
title: Erotic museum's creator is gone; her brainchild could be leaving
text:
The Orthodox Jewish grandmother who founded and operated the World Erotic Art Museum ( www.weam.com ) may be gone, but the X-rated museum is still open, although its days could be numbered.
Naomi Wilzig, the feisty 80-year-old widow of a multimillionaire Holocaust survivor, created the museum in 2005 to exhibit her collection of more than 4,000 erotic artworks. She died in April, barely two months after hosting what her invitations facetiously listed as a museum Seduction Party on Valentine's Day.
New Yorker Ivan Wilzig, 59, eldest of the three Wilzig sibling heirs, said Berlin's Humboldt University has expressed an interest in acquiring his mother's erotic art, and he's had discussions with university officials.
Have you taken in all the local museums' exhibits? Looking for new ground to tackle? Well, TripAdvisor.com's latest list will have you salivating. Travelers proffered their take on the top-rated museums around the globe.
"We're not interested in being in the museum business," he stressed, "but we do want to perpetuate my mother's legacy, educating people about sex and removing its crazy stigmas and taboos.
"Of course, my father, who survived Auschwitz, would probably turn over in his grave, knowing we were negotiating with a German college and the collection could end up there. But Germany today is not the 1930s Germany he knew. Its Jewish population is increasing. And, frankly, I feel safer in Berlin than in Jerusalem, where terrorism is a constant fear."
Siggi Wilzig, his father, was president and CEO of the Trust Co. of New Jersey, president and CEO of the Wilshire Oil Co. and a director of the U.S. Holocaust Museum in Washington.
Naomi Wilzig seemed like the last person you'd expect to find in an erotic art museum, let alone operating one.
"Please emphasize that we're promoting education, not pornography," she urged me last year.
Displayed are nude paintings, cartoons and sculptures with many items explicitly depicting various aspects of sex play, some dating to biblical times. There are authenticated signed erotic sketches by Rembrandt, Picasso, Salvador Dali and Toulouse-Lautrec.
Wilzig wrote five books, picturing items from her erotica collection, and for her philanthropic and cultural contributions, she received numerous honors, including honorary doctor degrees from the Rabbinical College of America, headquartered in Morristown, N.J., and San Francisco's Institute for Advanced Study of Human Sexuality.
Admission is $14, and children under 18 are not admitted. Open 11 a.m. to 10 p.m. Monday to Thursday, 11 a.m. to midnight Friday and Sunday. 1205 Washington Ave., Miami Beach, Fla.; 305-532-9336.
Si Liberman is a freelance writer.
